column1: Pully (French pronunciation: ​[pyˈji]) is a municipality in Switzerland in the canton of Vaud
column2: located in the district of Lavaux-Oron. It is one of the eastern suburbs of the city of Lausanne
column3: located on the shores of Lake Geneva (Lac Léman) and at the foot of the vineyards of Lavaux on the road to Vevey and Montreux.

column1: Pully is first mentioned in 994 as Pulliacum.
In 1826 a neolithic cemetery with about 30 graves was uncovered at Pierra-Portray.  However
column2: the artifacts were not fully preserved and only one flint blade and a soapstone fragment still exist.  Near Pierra-Portray
column3: along the Chemin de Chamblandes
column4: Albert Naef examined 23 tombs in 1901-10.  These tombs belonging to a similar set of tombs which were sporadically excavated and recorded between 1880-1993.  The local rectangular graves consisted of boxes assembled from four vertical slabs of about 1 meter (3.3 ft) in length
column5: with a fifth plate that served as a lid.  The dead were lying on their left side with their legs drawn up to the chest and the head pointed to the east.  The largest find of stone box graves in Pully was the cemetery at Chamblandes.  Due to the number of finds at Chamblandes
column6: all similar cist or stone box graves in the surrounding area came to be known as Chamblandes type graves.  The cemetery of Chamblandes extends over a length of about a hundred meters (yards) and included 76 graves and over 100 skeletons.  This Middle Neolithic (4300-3900 BC) graveyard included as grave goods; ocher

column11: a dagger and a bronze knife-blade hatchet are attributed to an early Bronze Age grave.  In 1992 a cremation grave was discovered that dated from the Late Bronze Age.

column2: while working on foundation of a terrace of the Le Prieuré building
column3: the corner of a large Roman era villa was discovered.  The villa dates from the period between the second half of the 1st Century and 4th Century AD.  The accompanying small thermal baths
column4: a monumental pool and several walls were already known from earlier excavations.  The heart of the east wing of the villa is a multi-level
column5: semi-circular pavilion.  The lower hall is decorated with
column7: wall paintings which represent a chariot race.  The painting dates from the first quarter of the 2nd Century.  Finds from the 4th and 5th Centuries show that the site was also
column9: during the late antiquity period.  Between the 5th and 6th Century
column10: the baths were converted into a Christian burial chapel with numerous burials.

column1: During the Carolingian era the additional buildings were built around the burial chapel.  During the Early Middle Ages  (5th-7th century) a cemetery was operating at Les Deserts.In the 10th Century the royal family of Burgundy granted their vineyards at Pully to Payerne Priory.  The priory retained this land in Pully until 1536.  In 1079
column2: Bishop Burkhard of Oltigen received some property from the Emperor in Pully.  This land had previously belonged to Rudolf of Swabia.  From then on
column3: the Bishop of Lausanne possessed the jurisdiction right over the bailiwick of Pully.  The Bishop first granted the bailiwick to the Lords of Faucigny
column4: then in 1276 to the de Thoire-Villars family.  Two officers
column5: the Sautier or Weibel and the Seneschal
column6: were responsible for the judiciary.  The Counts of Geneva
column8: were the Seneschals until 1536 and were practically the rulers of Pully.  A number of other religious and secular leaders owned land or rights in the village.  Until 1555
column9: the Counts of Gruyere were one of the largest landowners in the area.  In 1509
column10: Bern and Fribourg mediated between the Count of Gruyere and the citizens of Pully.  The market buildings in Pully were used until at least 1558.The municipality began to become a partly independent town in the 13th century and received its charter (plaict général) in 1368.  The town was administered by a twelve-member council until 1719
column11: when it became an eleven-member group.  The council was led by a knight banneret.

column2: the town of Pully came under the administration of the cities of Bern and Lausanne.  Lausanne renounced their rights in 1717.  From  1536 until 1798 it belonged to the Bailiwick of Lausanne.  Then
column3: from 1798 until 2006
column4: it was in the district of Lausanne.  The Le Prieuré building was originally the priory court of the Priory of Payerne.  Under the Bernese it served as a wine cellar and vineyard house.

column1: The original parish church was probably dedicated to St. Maurice starting in the 9th Century.  Between the 14th and 16th Century
column2: it was rebuilt and consecrated to St. Germann.  It burned down in 2001 and was rebuilt again in 2004.  After the Reformation
column3: the parish also included Paudex and Belmont
column4: which became independent in 1897.  The parsonage was built between 1594 and rebuilt in 1723.  The church in Chamblandes dates from 1938
column5: the one in La Rosiaz from 1953 and the Catholic Parish of St. Mauritius was created in 1954.

column1: Pully has an average of 120.3 days of rain or snow per year and on average receives 1
column2: 116 mm (43.9 in) of precipitation.  The wettest month is June during which time Pully receives an average of 115 mm (4.5 in) of rain or snow.  During this month there is precipitation for an average of 11.3 days.  The month with the most days of precipitation is May

column4: but with only 101 mm (4.0 in) of rain or snow.  The driest month of the year is February with an average of 73 mm (2.9 in) of precipitation over 9.7 days.  The Köppen Climate Classification subtype for this climate is "Cfb" (Marine West Coast Climate).

column2: Pully has 2 train stations
column3: called Pully-Nord and Pully.  This is because the train line leaving Lausanne toward the east splits in two
column4: with one line heading northwards toward Bern and the other heading east toward the Simplon Tunnel
column5: each passing through Pully.  Both stations are served by trains of the RER Vaud commuter rail network.
